repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
To the best of my knowledge, these match the mappings in vim-unimpaired exactly: https://github.com/tpope/vim-unimpaired/blob/master/plugin/unimpaired.vim

This does not include _all_ of unimpaired's mappings, just the simple ones. For instance, this does not add `[f` or `]f` or any of the option mappings (e.g. `[os` or `yos`). We could perhaps do those later, but this first batch includes the least controversial mappings.

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -169,6 +169,172 @@ do
       vim.lsp.buf.signature_help()
     end, { desc = 'vim.lsp.buf.signature_help()' })
   end
+
+  --- vim-unimpaired style mappings. See: https://github.com/tpope/vim-unimpaired
+  do
+    -- Quickfix mappings
+    vim.keymap.set('n', '[q', function()
+      vim.cmd.cprevious({ count = vim.v.count1 })
+    end, {
+      desc = ':cprevious',
+    })
+
+    vim.keymap.set('n', ']q', function()
+      vim.cmd.cnext({ count = vim.v.count1 })
+    end, {
+      desc = ':cnext',
+    })
+
+    vim.keymap.set('n', '[Q', function()
+      vim.cmd.crewind({ args = vim.v.count ~= 0 and { vim.v.count } or nil })
+    end, {
+      desc = ':crewind',
+    })
+
+    vim.keymap.set('n', '[Q', function()

comment_data.body: (not a blocker) most of these mappings would probably benefit from regular `vim.cmd[[nnoremap ...]]` definitions instead of Lua functions. The `desc` for these Lua mappings is a workaround, but actually gives less clarity for no advantage.

comment_data.body:
probably helpful to call out vim-unimpaired explicitly:
```suggestion
  • Mappings inspired by Tim Pope's vim-unimpaired:
    • |[q|, |]q|, |[Q|, |]Q|, |[CTRL-Q|, |]CTRL-Q| navigate through the |quickfix| list
```

     |CTRL-W_d-default|

comment_data.body:
I disagree. We need to leave that esoteric DSL in the dust.

If we want to avoid the `desc`, then can't we pass a string instead of a function for RHS? That would clean this up a lot and make each mapping one line.

comment_data.body:
I never understood the use of the argument list. Why would one use this over `bnext` and `bprev`?

EDIT: this explains it well: https://www.reddit.com/r/vim/comments/u3nv6/buffer_list_vs_arguments_list/ . Sounds useful, especially now LSP is a thing.

comment_data.body:
>If we want to avoid the desc, then can't we pass a string instead of a function for RHS? That would clean this up a lot and make each mapping one line.

Some of these are nontrivial on a single line and would still require a description. I'm not sure why we're so concerned about avoiding the description or keeping things to one line. Using `vim.cmd` is structured, explicit with counts (avoiding the `:` vs `<Cmd>` distinction), and lets us keep the implementation and human readable description separate.
comment_data.diff_hunk:

+    end, {
+      desc = ':cprevious',

comment_regular_data.body:
>IMO it would be clearer to define these in vimscript (vim.cmd[[...]]), while also making it easier to diff against "upstream" vim-unimpaired.

vim-unimpaired uses parameterized helper functions to create the mappings, so even if we used `vim.cmd` it would not be a trivial 1:1 diff. And unimpaired changes infrequently enough (the last update was 2 years ago) that any diffs can easily be done "manually".

>LGTM assuming that these match vim-unimpaired's respective definitions

There are some minor differences. For example, for `[Q` we use `:clast` with an argument if a count is given, while unimpaired.vim uses `:cc` if there is a count or `:clast` otherwise. This is a nice benefit of using `vim.cmd` by the way, it means we can use `vim.cmd.clast({ args = vim.v.count ~= 0 and { vim.v.count } or nil })` instead of `:<C-U><C-R>=v:count ? v:count . "cc" : "clast"<CR><CR>`. The former is structured and (in my opinion) easier to understand than the latter (and I am saying that as someone who has written their fair share of Vimscript).

Although it deviates from 'vim-unimpaired' and requires more code to implement, I'd still like to mention an observation.

Currently all uppercase mappings (`[Q` / `]Q`, etc.) have duplicating functionality when it comes to respecting `[count]`: "Go to the item number `[count]`". Another approach would be to treat it as "Step `[count]-1` times forward/backward starting from first/last item". So `5[Q` will go to 5-th item while `5]Q` will go to 5-th last item. This definition also opens the door for adding wrapping around edges for items which currently don't support that (quickfix, loclist).

As a followup we should consider @mfussenegger 's https://github.com/mfussenegger/nvim-overfly/

> So `5[Q` will go to 5-th item while `5]Q` will go to 5-th last item

That sounds cool, in favor of a followup to do that @echasnovski

title: feat(defaults): add default unimpaired style mappings
